output.conclusion: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental principles and advanced concepts in the Theory of Machines, equipping students with the knowledge and skills necessary for analyzing and designing mechanical systems.
output.introduction: Welcome to the Advanced Theory of Machines course. This course delves into the kinematics and dynamics of machinery, covering topics such as mechanisms, gear trains, balancing, vibrations, and control systems.

chapters.description: Introduction to kinematic chains, degrees of freedom, Grubler's criterion, and Kutzbach criterion. Detailed analysis of four-bar linkages, slider-crank mechanisms, and other common mechanisms.
Vector loop method, instantaneous center method, and relative velocity method for determining velocities and accelerations of links in mechanisms.
Application of complex numbers and complex algebra for analyzing the motion of mechanisms. Derivation of velocity and acceleration equations using complex algebra.
Free-body diagrams, equilibrium equations, and static force analysis of mechanisms. Determination of forces and torques required for static equilibrium.
Inertia forces and torques, D'Alembert's principle, and dynamic force analysis of mechanisms. Balancing of rotating and reciprocating masses.
Analysis of forces in reciprocating engines, including piston effort, connecting rod force, and crankshaft torque. Turning moment diagrams and flywheel design.
Introduction to gear types, gear tooth profiles, involute curves, and gear terminology. Calculation of gear ratios, center distances, and contact ratios.
Simple gear trains, compound gear trains, reverted gear trains, and epicyclic gear trains. Analysis of gear train velocity ratios and torque transmission.
Forces between meshing gears, gear tooth loading, and gear train efficiency. Design considerations for gear trains to minimize wear and maximize power transmission.
Balancing of rotating masses, single-plane balancing, and multi-plane balancing. Static and dynamic unbalance and their effects on machine vibration.
Description of balancing machines, including static balancing machines and dynamic balancing machines. Procedures for balancing rotating machinery.
Partial balancing of reciprocating masses, primary and secondary unbalance, and methods for reducing vibration in reciprocating machinery.

modules.moduleTitle: Balancing of Rotating and Reciprocating Masses

chapters.description: Single degree of freedom systems, natural frequency, damping, and damped free vibration. Logarithmic decrement and damping ratio.
Harmonic excitation, resonance, transmissibility, and vibration isolation. Analysis of vibration absorbers and vibration dampers.
Equations of motion, natural frequencies, mode shapes, and modal analysis. Vibration analysis of continuous systems.
Open-loop and closed-loop control systems, feedback control, and control system components. Transfer functions and block diagrams.
Routh-Hurwitz criterion, root locus method, and Bode plots for analyzing the stability of control systems. Design of compensators for improving system stability.
Applications of control systems in machinery, including speed control, position control, and force control. Case studies of control system design for specific machines.
